text: After the death of Moses the servant of the Lord, the Lord said to Joshua son of Nun, Moses’ assistant:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Moses my servant is dead. Now then, you and all these people, get ready to cross the River Jordan into the land I am about to give to them – to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you every place where you set your foot, as I promised Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your territory will extend from the desert to Lebanon, and from the great river, the Euphrates – all the Hittite country – to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one will be able to stand against you all the days of your life. As I was with Moses, so I will be with you; I will never leave you nor forsake you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and courageous, because you will lead these people to inherit the land I swore to their ancestors to give them.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Be strong and very courageous. Be careful to obey all the law my servant Moses gave you; do not turn from it to the right or to the left, that you may be successful wherever you go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep this Book of the Law always on your lips; meditate on it day and night, so that you may be careful to do everything written in it. Then you will be prosperous and successful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged, for the Lord your God will be with you wherever you go.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua ordered the officers of the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go through the camp and tell the people, “Get your provisions ready. Three days from now you will cross the Jordan here to go in and take possession of the land the Lord your God is giving you for your own.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the Reubenites, the Gadites and the half-tribe of Manasseh, Joshua said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Remember the command that Moses the servant of the Lord gave you after he said, “The Lord your God will give you rest by giving you this land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Your wives, your children and your livestock may stay in the land that Moses gave you east of the Jordan, but all your fighting men, ready for battle, must cross over ahead of your fellow Israelites. You are to help them
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord gives them rest, as he has done for you, and until they too have taken possession of the land that the Lord your God is giving them. After that, you may go back and occupy your own land, which Moses the servant of the Lord gave you east of the Jordan towards the sunrise.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they answered Joshua, ‘Whatever you have commanded us we will do, and wherever you send us we will go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as we fully obeyed Moses, so we will obey you. Only may the Lord your God be with you as he was with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever rebels against your word and does not obey it, whatever you may command them, will be put to death. Only be strong and courageous!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua son of Nun secretly sent two spies from Shittim. ‘Go, look over the land,’ he said, ‘especially Jericho.’ So they went and entered the house of a prostitute named Rahab and stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Jericho was told, ‘Look, some of the Israelites have come here tonight to spy out the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Jericho sent this message to Rahab: ‘Bring out the men who came to you and entered your house, because they have come to spy out the whole land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman had taken the two men and hidden them. She said, ‘Yes, the men came to me, but I did not know where they had come from.
speaker: Narrator

text: At dusk, when it was time to close the city gate, they left. I don’t know which way they went. Go after them quickly. You may catch up with them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: (But she had taken them up to the roof and hidden them under the stalks of flax she had laid out on the roof.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men set out in pursuit of the spies on the road that leads to the fords of the Jordan, and as soon as the pursuers had gone out, the gate was shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before the spies lay down for the night, she went up on the roof
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to them, ‘I know that the Lord has given this land to you and that a great fear of you has fallen on us, so that all who live in this country are melting in fear because of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have heard how the Lord dried up the water of the Red Sea for you when you came out of Egypt, and what you did to Sihon and Og, the two kings of the Amorites east of the Jordan, whom you completely destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we heard of it, our hearts sank and everyone’s courage failed because of you, for the Lord your God is God in heaven above and on the earth below.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now then, please swear to me by the Lord that you will show kindness to my family, because I have shown kindness to you. Give me a sure sign
speaker: Narrator

text: that you will spare the lives of my father and mother, my brothers and sisters, and all who belong to them – and that you will save us from death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Our lives for your lives!’ the men assured her. ‘If you don’t tell what we are doing, we will treat you kindly and faithfully when the Lord gives us the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So she let them down by a rope through the window, for the house she lived in was part of the city wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to them, ‘Go to the hills so that the pursuers will not find you. Hide yourselves there for three days until they return, and then go on your way.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the men had said to her, ‘This oath you made us swear will not be binding on us
speaker: Narrator

text: unless, when we enter the land, you have tied this scarlet cord in the window through which you let us down, and unless you have brought your father and mother, your brothers and all your family into your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any of them go outside your house into the street, their blood will be on their own heads; we will not be responsible. As for those who are in the house with you, their blood will be on our head if a hand is laid on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you tell what we are doing, we will be released from the oath you made us swear.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Agreed,’ she replied. ‘Let it be as you say.’
So she sent them away, and they departed. And she tied the scarlet cord in the window.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they left, they went into the hills and stayed there three days, until the pursuers had searched all along the road and returned without finding them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two men started back. They went down out of the hills, forded the river and came to Joshua son of Nun and told him everything that had happened to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Joshua, ‘The Lord has surely given the whole land into our hands; all the people are melting in fear because of us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning Joshua and all the Israelites set out from Shittim and went to the Jordan, where they camped before crossing over.
speaker: Narrator

text: After three days the officers went throughout the camp,
speaker: Narrator

text: giving orders to the people: ‘When you see the ark of the covenant of the Lord your God, and the Levitical priests carrying it, you are to move out from your positions and follow it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know which way to go, since you have never been this way before. But keep a distance of about two thousand cubits between you and the ark; do not go near it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told the people, ‘Consecrate yourselves, for tomorrow the Lord will do amazing things among you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to the priests, ‘Take up the ark of the covenant and pass on ahead of the people.’ So they took it up and went ahead of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Joshua, ‘Today I will begin to exalt you in the eyes of all Israel, so that they may know that I am with you as I was with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the priests who carry the ark of the covenant: “When you reach the edge of the Jordan’s waters, go and stand in the river.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to the Israelites, ‘Come here and listen to the words of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you will know that the living God is among you and that he will certainly drive out before you the Canaanites, Hittites, Hivites, Perizzites, Girgashites, Amorites and Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, the ark of the covenant of the Lord of all the earth will go into the Jordan ahead of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, choose twelve men from the tribes of Israel, one from each tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as soon as the priests who carry the ark of the Lord – the Lord of all the earth – set foot in the Jordan, its waters flowing downstream will be cut off and stand up in a heap.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the people broke camp to cross the Jordan, the priests carrying the ark of the covenant went ahead of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Jordan is in flood all during harvest. Yet as soon as the priests who carried the ark reached the Jordan and their feet touched the water’s edge,
speaker: Narrator

text: the water from upstream stopped flowing. It piled up in a heap a great distance away, at a town called Adam in the vicinity of Zarethan, while the water flowing down to the Sea of the Arabah (that is, the Dead Sea) was completely cut off. So the people crossed over opposite Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord stopped in the middle of the Jordan and stood on dry ground, while all Israel passed by until the whole nation had completed the crossing on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the whole nation had finished crossing the Jordan, the Lord said to Joshua,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Choose twelve men from among the people, one from each tribe,
speaker: Narrator

text: and tell them to take up twelve stones from the middle of the Jordan, from right where the priests are standing, and carry them over with you and put them down at the place where you stay tonight.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua called together the twelve men he had appointed from the Israelites, one from each tribe,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to them, ‘Go over before the ark of the Lord your God into the middle of the Jordan. Each of you is to take up a stone on his shoulder, according to the number of the tribes of the Israelites,
speaker: Narrator

text: to serve as a sign among you. In the future, when your children ask you, “What do these stones mean?”
speaker: Narrator

text: tell them that the flow of the Jordan was cut off before the ark of the covenant of the Lord. When it crossed the Jordan, the waters of the Jordan were cut off. These stones are to be a memorial to the people of Israel for ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites did as Joshua commanded them. They took twelve stones from the middle of the Jordan, according to the number of the tribes of the Israelites, as the Lord had told Joshua; and they carried them over with them to their camp, where they put them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua set up the twelve stones that had been in the middle of the Jordan at the spot where the priests who carried the ark of the covenant had stood. And they are there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the priests who carried the ark remained standing in the middle of the Jordan until everything the Lord had commanded Joshua was done by the people, just as Moses had directed Joshua. The people hurried over,
speaker: Narrator

text: and as soon as all of them had crossed, the ark of the Lord and the priests came to the other side while the people watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Reuben, Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh crossed over, ready for battle, in front of the Israelites, as Moses had directed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: About forty thousand armed for battle crossed over before the Lord to the plains of Jericho for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day the Lord exalted Joshua in the sight of all Israel; and they stood in awe of him all the days of his life, just as they had stood in awe of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Joshua,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Command the priests carrying the ark of the covenant law to come up out of the Jordan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua commanded the priests, ‘Come up out of the Jordan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priests came up out of the river carrying the ark of the covenant of the Lord. No sooner had they set their feet on the dry ground than the waters of the Jordan returned to their place and ran in flood as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of the first month the people went up from the Jordan and camped at Gilgal on the eastern border of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua set up at Gilgal the twelve stones they had taken out of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the Israelites, ‘In the future when your descendants ask their parents, “What do these stones mean?”
speaker: Narrator

text: tell them, “Israel crossed the Jordan on dry ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God dried up the Jordan before you until you had crossed over. The Lord your God did to the Jordan what he had done to the Red Sea when he dried it up before us until we had crossed over.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this so that all the peoples of the earth might know that the hand of the Lord is powerful and so that you might always fear the Lord your God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when all the Amorite kings west of the Jordan and all the Canaanite kings along the coast heard how the Lord had dried up the Jordan before the Israelites until they had crossed over, their hearts melted in fear and they no longer had the courage to face the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord said to Joshua, ‘Make flint knives and circumcise the Israelites again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua made flint knives and circumcised the Israelites at Gibeath Haaraloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this is why he did so: all those who came out of Egypt – all the men of military age – died in the wilderness on the way after leaving Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people that came out had been circumcised, but all the people born in the wilderness during the journey from Egypt had not.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites had moved about in the wilderness for forty years until all the men who were of military age when they left Egypt had died, since they had not obeyed the Lord. For the Lord had sworn to them that they would not see the land that he had solemnly promised their ancestors to give us, a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he raised up their sons in their place, and these were the ones Joshua circumcised. They were still uncircumcised because they had not been circumcised on the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after the whole nation had been circumcised, they remained where they were in camp until they were healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Joshua, ‘Today I have rolled away the reproach of Egypt from you.’ So the place has been called Gilgal to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the evening of the fourteenth day of the month, while camped at Gilgal on the plains of Jericho, the Israelites celebrated the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: The day after the Passover, that very day, they ate some of the produce of the land: unleavened bread and roasted grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The manna stopped the day after they ate this food from the land; there was no longer any manna for the Israelites, but that year they ate the produce of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Joshua was near Jericho, he looked up and saw a man standing in front of him with a drawn sword in his hand. Joshua went up to him and asked, ‘Are you for us or for our enemies?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Neither,’ he replied, ‘but as commander of the army of the Lord I have now come.’ Then Joshua fell face down to the ground in reverence, and asked him, ‘What message does my Lord have for his servant?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The commander of the Lord’s army replied, ‘Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy.’ And Joshua did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the gates of Jericho were securely barred because of the Israelites. No one went out and no one came in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Joshua, ‘See, I have delivered Jericho into your hands, along with its king and its fighting men.
speaker: Narrator

text: March round the city once with all the armed men. Do this for six days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make seven priests carry trumpets of rams’ horns in front of the ark. On the seventh day, march round the city seven times, with the priests blowing the trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear them sound a long blast on the trumpets, make the whole army give a loud shout; then the wall of the city will collapse and the army will go up, everyone straight in.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua son of Nun called the priests and said to them, ‘Take up the ark of the covenant of the Lord and make seven priests carry trumpets in front of it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And he ordered the army, ‘Advance! March round the city, with an armed guard going ahead of the ark of the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua had spoken to the people, the seven priests carrying the seven trumpets before the Lord went forwards, blowing their trumpets, and the ark of the Lord’s covenant followed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The armed guard marched ahead of the priests who blew the trumpets, and the rear guard followed the ark. All this time the trumpets were sounding.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joshua had commanded the army, ‘Do not give a war cry, do not raise your voices, do not say a word until the day I tell you to shout. Then shout!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he had the ark of the Lord carried round the city, circling it once. Then the army returned to camp and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua got up early the next morning and the priests took up the ark of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven priests carrying the seven trumpets went forwards, marching before the ark of the Lord and blowing the trumpets. The armed men went ahead of them and the rear guard followed the ark of the Lord, while the trumpets kept sounding.
speaker: Narrator

text: So on the second day they marched round the city once and returned to the camp. They did this for six days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day, they got up at daybreak and marched round the city seven times in the same manner, except that on that day they circled the city seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh time round, when the priests sounded the trumpet blast, Joshua commanded the army, ‘Shout! For the Lord has given you the city!
speaker: Narrator

text: The city and all that is in it are to be devoted to the Lord. Only Rahab the prostitute and all who are with her in her house shall be spared, because she hid the spies we sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: But keep away from the devoted things, so that you will not bring about your own destruction by taking any of them. Otherwise you will make the camp of Israel liable to destruction and bring trouble on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the silver and gold and the articles of bronze and iron are sacred to the Lord and must go into his treasury.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the trumpets sounded, the army shouted, and at the sound of the trumpet, when the men gave a loud shout, the wall collapsed; so everyone charged straight in, and they took the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They devoted the city to the Lord and destroyed with the sword every living thing in it – men and women, young and old, cattle, sheep and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to the two men who had spied out the land, ‘Go into the prostitute’s house and bring her out and all who belong to her, in accordance with your oath to her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young men who had done the spying went in and brought out Rahab, her father and mother, her brothers and sisters and all who belonged to her. They brought out her entire family and put them in a place outside the camp of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they burned the whole city and everything in it, but they put the silver and gold and the articles of bronze and iron into the treasury of the Lord’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joshua spared Rahab the prostitute, with her family and all who belonged to her, because she hid the men Joshua had sent as spies to Jericho – and she lives among the Israelites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that time Joshua pronounced this solemn oath: ‘Cursed before the Lord is the one who undertakes to rebuild this city, Jericho:
‘At the cost of his firstborn son
    he will lay its foundations;
at the cost of his youngest
    he will set up its gates.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord was with Joshua, and his fame spread throughout the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites were unfaithful in regard to the devoted things; Achan son of Karmi, the son of Zimri, the son of Zerah, of the tribe of Judah, took some of them. So the Lord’s anger burned against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joshua sent men from Jericho to Ai, which is near Beth Aven to the east of Bethel, and told them, ‘Go up and spy out the region.’ So the men went up and spied out Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they returned to Joshua, they said, ‘Not all the army will have to go up against Ai. Send two or three thousand men to take it and do not weary the whole army, for only a few people live there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So about three thousand went up; but they were routed by the men of Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: who killed about thirty-six of them. They chased the Israelites from the city gate as far as the stone quarries and struck them down on the slopes. At this the hearts of the people melted in fear and became like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua tore his clothes and fell face down to the ground before the ark of the Lord, remaining there till evening. The elders of Israel did the same, and sprinkled dust on their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua said, ‘Alas, Sovereign Lord, why did you ever bring this people across the Jordan to deliver us into the hands of the Amorites to destroy us? If only we had been content to stay on the other side of the Jordan!
speaker: Narrator

text: Pardon your servant, Lord. What can I say, now that Israel has been routed by its enemies?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Canaanites and the other people of the country will hear about this and they will surround us and wipe out our name from the earth. What then will you do for your own great name?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Joshua, ‘Stand up! What are you doing down on your face?
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel has sinned; they have violated my covenant, which I commanded them to keep. They have taken some of the devoted things; they have stolen, they have lied, they have put them with their own possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why the Israelites cannot stand against their enemies; they turn their backs and run because they have been made liable to destruction. I will not be with you any more unless you destroy whatever among you is devoted to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go, consecrate the people. Tell them, “Consecrate yourselves in preparation for tomorrow; for this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: there are devoted things among you, Israel. You cannot stand against your enemies until you remove them.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“In the morning, present yourselves tribe by tribe. The tribe that the Lord chooses shall come forward clan by clan; the clan that the Lord chooses shall come forward family by family; and the family that the Lord chooses shall come forward man by man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever is caught with the devoted things shall be destroyed by fire, along with all that belongs to him. He has violated the covenant of the Lord and has done an outrageous thing in Israel!”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning Joshua made Israel come forward by tribes, and Judah was chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clans of Judah came forward, and the Zerahites were chosen. He made the clan of the Zerahites come forward by families, and Zimri was chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua made his family come forward man by man, and Achan son of Karmi, the son of Zimri, the son of Zerah, of the tribe of Judah, was chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua said to Achan, ‘My son, give glory to the Lord, the God of Israel, and honour him. Tell me what you have done; do not hide it from me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Achan replied, ‘It is true! I have sinned against the Lord, the God of Israel. This is what I have done:
speaker: Narrator

text: when I saw in the plunder a beautiful robe from Babylonia, two hundred shekels of silver and a bar of gold weighing fifty shekels, I coveted them and took them. They are hidden in the ground inside my tent, with the silver underneath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua sent messengers, and they ran to the tent, and there it was, hidden in his tent, with the silver underneath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the things from the tent, brought them to Joshua and all the Israelites and spread them out before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua, together with all Israel, took Achan son of Zerah, the silver, the robe, the gold bar, his sons and daughters, his cattle, donkeys and sheep, his tent and all that he had, to the Valley of Achor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joshua said, ‘Why have you brought this trouble on us? The Lord will bring trouble on you today.’
Then all Israel stoned him, and after they had stoned the rest, they burned them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over Achan they heaped up a large pile of rocks, which remains to this day. Then the Lord turned from his fierce anger. Therefore that place has been called the Valley of Achor ever since.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Joshua, ‘Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged. Take the whole army with you, and go up and attack Ai. For I have delivered into your hands the king of Ai, his people, his city and his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall do to Ai and its king as you did to Jericho and its king, except that you may carry off their plunder and livestock for yourselves. Set an ambush behind the city.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua and the whole army moved out to attack Ai. He chose thirty thousand of his best fighting men and sent them out at night
speaker: Narrator

text: with these orders: ‘Listen carefully. You are to set an ambush behind the city. Don’t go very far from it. All of you be on the alert.
speaker: Narrator

text: I and all those with me will advance on the city, and when the men come out against us, as they did before, we will flee from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will pursue us until we have lured them away from the city, for they will say, “They are running away from us as they did before.” So when we flee from them,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are to rise up from ambush and take the city. The Lord your God will give it into your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have taken the city, set it on fire. Do what the Lord has commanded. See to it; you have my orders.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua sent them off, and they went to the place of ambush and lay in wait between Bethel and Ai, to the west of Ai – but Joshua spent that night with the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning Joshua mustered his army, and he and the leaders of Israel marched before them to Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire force that was with him marched up and approached the city and arrived in front of it. They set up camp north of Ai, with the valley between them and the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua had taken about five thousand men and set them in ambush between Bethel and Ai, to the west of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the soldiers took up their positions – with the main camp to the north of the city and the ambush to the west of it. That night Joshua went into the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Ai saw this, he and all the men of the city hurried out early in the morning to meet Israel in battle at a certain place overlooking the Arabah. But he did not know that an ambush had been set against him behind the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel let themselves be driven back before them, and they fled towards the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Ai were called to pursue them, and they pursued Joshua and were lured away from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not a man remained in Ai or Bethel who did not go after Israel. They left the city open and went in pursuit of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Joshua, ‘Hold out towards Ai the javelin that is in your hand, for into your hand I will deliver the city.’ So Joshua held out towards the city the javelin that was in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he did this, the men in the ambush rose quickly from their position and rushed forward. They entered the city and captured it and quickly set it on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Ai looked back and saw the smoke of the city rising up into the sky, but they had no chance to escape in any direction; the Israelites who had been fleeing towards the wilderness had turned back against their pursuers.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when Joshua and all Israel saw that the ambush had taken the city and that smoke was going up from the city, they turned round and attacked the men of Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those in the ambush also came out of the city against them, so that they were caught in the middle, with Israelites on both sides. Israel cut them down, leaving them neither survivors nor fugitives.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they took the king of Ai alive and brought him to Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel had finished killing all the men of Ai in the fields and in the wilderness where they had chased them, and when every one of them had been put to the sword, all the Israelites returned to Ai and killed those who were in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Twelve thousand men and women fell that day – all the people of Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Joshua did not draw back the hand that held out his javelin until he had destroyed all who lived in Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Israel did carry off for themselves the livestock and plunder of this city, as the Lord had instructed Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua burned Ai and made it a permanent heap of ruins, a desolate place to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He impaled the body of the king of Ai on a pole and left it there until evening. At sunset, Joshua ordered them to take the body from the pole and throw it down at the entrance of the city gate. And they raised a large pile of rocks over it, which remains to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua built on Mount Ebal an altar to the Lord, the God of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: as Moses the servant of the Lord had commanded the Israelites. He built it according to what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses – an altar of uncut stones, on which no iron tool had been used. On it they offered to the Lord burnt offerings and sacrificed fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: There, in the presence of the Israelites, Joshua wrote on stones a copy of the law of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites, with their elders, officials and judges, were standing on both sides of the ark of the covenant of the Lord, facing the Levitical priests who carried it. Both the foreigners living among them and the native-born were there. Half of the people stood in front of Mount Gerizim and half of them in front of Mount Ebal, as Moses the servant of the Lord had formerly commanded when he gave instructions to bless the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, Joshua read all the words of the law – the blessings and the curses – just as it is written in the Book of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was not a word of all that Moses had commanded that Joshua did not read to the whole assembly of Israel, including the women and children, and the foreigners who lived among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when all the kings west of the Jordan heard about these things – the kings in the hill country, in the western foothills, and along the entire coast of the Mediterranean Sea as far as Lebanon (the kings of the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites) –
speaker: Narrator

text: they came together to wage war against Joshua and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, when the people of Gibeon heard what Joshua had done to Jericho and Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: they resorted to a ruse: they went as a delegation whose donkeys were loaded with worn-out sacks and old wineskins, cracked and mended.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put worn and patched sandals on their feet and wore old clothes. All the bread of their food supply was dry and mouldy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went to Joshua in the camp at Gilgal and said to him and the Israelites, ‘We have come from a distant country; make a treaty with us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to the Hivites, ‘But perhaps you live near us, so how can we make a treaty with you?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘We are your servants,’ they said to Joshua.
But Joshua asked, ‘Who are you and where do you come from?’
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered: ‘Your servants have come from a very distant country because of the fame of the Lord your God. For we have heard reports of him: all that he did in Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all that he did to the two kings of the Amorites east of the Jordan – Sihon king of Heshbon, and Og king of Bashan, who reigned in Ashtaroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And our elders and all those living in our country said to us, “Take provisions for your journey; go and meet them and say to them, ‘We are your servants; make a treaty with us.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: This bread of ours was warm when we packed it at home on the day we left to come to you. But now see how dry and mouldy it is.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these wineskins that we filled were new, but see how cracked they are. And our clothes and sandals are worn out by the very long journey.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites sampled their provisions but did not enquire of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua made a treaty of peace with them to let them live, and the leaders of the assembly ratified it by oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after they made the treaty with the Gibeonites, the Israelites heard that they were neighbours, living near them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites set out and on the third day came to their cities: Gibeon, Kephirah, Beeroth and Kiriath Jearim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Israelites did not attack them, because the leaders of the assembly had sworn an oath to them by the Lord, the God of Israel.
The whole assembly grumbled against the leaders,
speaker: Narrator

text: but all the leaders answered, ‘We have given them our oath by the Lord, the God of Israel, and we cannot touch them now.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what we will do to them: we will let them live, so that God’s wrath will not fall on us for breaking the oath we swore to them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They continued, ‘Let them live, but let them be woodcutters and water-carriers in the service of the whole assembly.’ So the leaders’ promise to them was kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua summoned the Gibeonites and said, ‘Why did you deceive us by saying, “We live a long way from you,” while actually you live near us?
speaker: Narrator

text: You are now under a curse: you will never be released from service as woodcutters and water-carriers for the house of my God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered Joshua, ‘Your servants were clearly told how the Lord your God had commanded his servant Moses to give you the whole land and to wipe out all its inhabitants from before you. So we feared for our lives because of you, and that is why we did this.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are now in your hands. Do to us whatever seems good and right to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua saved them from the Israelites, and they did not kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day he made the Gibeonites woodcutters and water-carriers for the assembly, to provide for the needs of the altar of the Lord at the place the Lord would choose. And that is what they are to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Adoni-Zedek king of Jerusalem heard that Joshua had taken Ai and totally destroyed it, doing to Ai and its king as he had done to Jericho and its king, and that the people of Gibeon had made a treaty of peace with Israel and had become their allies.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his people were very much alarmed at this, because Gibeon was an important city, like one of the royal cities; it was larger than Ai, and all its men were good fighters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Adoni-Zedek king of Jerusalem appealed to Hoham king of Hebron, Piram king of Jarmuth, Japhia king of Lachish and Debir king of Eglon.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Come up and help me attack Gibeon,’ he said, ‘because it has made peace with Joshua and the Israelites.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the five kings of the Amorites – the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish and Eglon – joined forces. They moved up with all their troops and took up positions against Gibeon and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gibeonites then sent word to Joshua in the camp at Gilgal: ‘Do not abandon your servants. Come up to us quickly and save us! Help us, because all the Amorite kings from the hill country have joined forces against us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua marched up from Gilgal with his entire army, including all the best fighting men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Joshua, ‘Do not be afraid of them; I have given them into your hand. Not one of them will be able to withstand you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After an all-night march from Gilgal, Joshua took them by surprise.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord threw them into confusion before Israel, so Joshua and the Israelites defeated them completely at Gibeon. Israel pursued them along the road going up to Beth Horon and cut them down all the way to Azekah and Makkedah.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they fled before Israel on the road down from Beth Horon to Azekah, the Lord hurled large hailstones down on them, and more of them died from the hail than were killed by the swords of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the day the Lord gave the Amorites over to Israel, Joshua said to the Lord in the presence of Israel:
‘Sun, stand still over Gibeon,
    and you, moon, over the Valley of Aijalon.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the sun stood still,
    and the moon stopped,
    till the nation avenged itself on its enemies,
as it is written in the Book of Jashar.
The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and delayed going down about a full day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There has never been a day like it before or since, a day when the Lord listened to a human being. Surely the Lord was fighting for Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua returned with all Israel to the camp at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the five kings had fled and hidden in the cave at Makkedah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua was told that the five kings had been found hiding in the cave at Makkedah,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said, ‘Roll large rocks up to the mouth of the cave, and post some men there to guard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t stop; pursue your enemies! Attack them from the rear and don’t let them reach their cities, for the Lord your God has given them into your hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua and the Israelites defeated them completely, but a few survivors managed to reach their fortified cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole army then returned safely to Joshua in the camp at Makkedah, and no one uttered a word against the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said, ‘Open the mouth of the cave and bring those five kings out to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought the five kings out of the cave – the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish and Eglon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had brought these kings to Joshua, he summoned all the men of Israel and said to the army commanders who had come with him, ‘Come here and put your feet on the necks of these kings.’ So they came forward and placed their feet on their necks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to them, ‘Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged. Be strong and courageous. This is what the Lord will do to all the enemies you are going to fight.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua put the kings to death and exposed their bodies on five poles, and they were left hanging on the poles until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: At sunset Joshua gave the order and they took them down from the poles and threw them into the cave where they had been hiding. At the mouth of the cave they placed large rocks, which are there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Joshua took Makkedah. He put the city and its king to the sword and totally destroyed everyone in it. He left no survivors. And he did to the king of Makkedah as he had done to the king of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel with him moved on from Makkedah to Libnah and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also gave that city and its king into Israel’s hand. The city and everyone in it Joshua put to the sword. He left no survivors there. And he did to its king as he had done to the king of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel with him moved on from Libnah to Lachish; he took up positions against it and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave Lachish into Israel’s hands, and Joshua took it on the second day. The city and everyone in it he put to the sword, just as he had done to Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Horam king of Gezer had come up to help Lachish, but Joshua defeated him and his army – until no survivors were left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel with him moved on from Lachish to Eglon; they took up positions against it and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They captured it that same day and put it to the sword and totally destroyed everyone in it, just as they had done to Lachish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel with him went up from Eglon to Hebron and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the city and put it to the sword, together with its king, its villages and everyone in it. They left no survivors. Just as at Eglon, they totally destroyed it and everyone in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel with him turned round and attacked Debir.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the city, its king and its villages, and put them to the sword. Everyone in it they totally destroyed. They left no survivors. They did to Debir and its king as they had done to Libnah and its king and to Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua subdued the whole region, including the hill country, the Negev, the western foothills and the mountain slopes, together with all their kings. He left no survivors. He totally destroyed all who breathed, just as the Lord, the God of Israel, had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua subdued them from Kadesh Barnea to Gaza and from the whole region of Goshen to Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these kings and their lands Joshua conquered in one campaign, because the Lord, the God of Israel, fought for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua returned with all Israel to the camp at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jabin king of Hazor heard of this, he sent word to Jobab king of Madon, to the kings of Shimron and Akshaph,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to the northern kings who were in the mountains, in the Arabah south of Kinnereth, in the western foothills and in Naphoth Dor on the west;
speaker: Narrator

text: to the Canaanites in the east and west; to the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites and Jebusites in the hill country; and to the Hivites below Hermon in the region of Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came out with all their troops and a large number of horses and chariots – a huge army, as numerous as the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these kings joined forces and made camp together at the Waters of Merom to fight against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Joshua, ‘Do not be afraid of them, because by this time tomorrow I will hand all of them, slain, over to Israel. You are to hamstring their horses and burn their chariots.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua and his whole army came against them suddenly at the Waters of Merom and attacked them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord gave them into the hand of Israel. They defeated them and pursued them all the way to Greater Sidon, to Misrephoth Maim, and to the Valley of Mizpah on the east, until no survivors were left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua did to them as the Lord had directed: he hamstrung their horses and burned their chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Joshua turned back and captured Hazor and put its king to the sword. (Hazor had been the head of all these kingdoms.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone in it they put to the sword. They totally destroyed them, not sparing anyone that breathed, and he burned Hazor itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua took all these royal cities and their kings and put them to the sword. He totally destroyed them, as Moses the servant of the Lord had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Israel did not burn any of the cities built on their mounds – except Hazor, which Joshua burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites carried off for themselves all the plunder and livestock of these cities, but all the people they put to the sword until they completely destroyed them, not sparing anyone that breathed.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord commanded his servant Moses, so Moses commanded Joshua, and Joshua did it; he left nothing undone of all that the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua took this entire land: the hill country, all the Negev, the whole region of Goshen, the western foothills, the Arabah and the mountains of Israel with their foothills,
speaker: Narrator

text: from Mount Halak, which rises towards Seir, to Baal Gad in the Valley of Lebanon below Mount Hermon. He captured all their kings and put them to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua waged war against all these kings for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Except for the Hivites living in Gibeon, not one city made a treaty of peace with the Israelites, who took them all in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it was the Lord himself who hardened their hearts to wage war against Israel, so that he might destroy them totally, exterminating them without mercy, as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Joshua went and destroyed the Anakites from the hill country: from Hebron, Debir and Anab, from all the hill country of Judah, and from all the hill country of Israel. Joshua totally destroyed them and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: No Anakites were left in Israelite territory; only in Gaza, Gath and Ashdod did any survive.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua took the entire land, just as the Lord had directed Moses, and he gave it as an inheritance to Israel according to their tribal divisions. Then the land had rest from war.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the kings of the land whom the Israelites had defeated and whose territory they took over east of the Jordan, from the Arnon Gorge to Mount Hermon, including all the eastern side of the Arabah:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon.
He ruled from Aroer on the rim of the Arnon Gorge – from the middle of the gorge – to the River Jabbok, which is the border of the Ammonites. This included half of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also ruled over the eastern Arabah from the Sea of Galilee to the Sea of the Arabah (that is, the Dead Sea), to Beth Jeshimoth, and then southward below the slopes of Pisgah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the territory of Og king of Bashan, one of the last of the Rephaites, who reigned in Ashtaroth and Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ruled over Mount Hermon, Salekah, all of Bashan to the border of the people of Geshur and Maakah, and half of Gilead to the border of Sihon king of Heshbon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, the servant of the Lord, and the Israelites conquered them. And Moses the servant of the Lord gave their land to the Reubenites, the Gadites and the half-tribe of Manasseh to be their possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is a list of the kings of the land that Joshua and the Israelites conquered on the west side of the Jordan, from Baal Gad in the Valley of Lebanon to Mount Halak, which rises towards Seir. Joshua gave their lands as an inheritance to the tribes of Israel according to their tribal divisions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lands included the hill country, the western foothills, the Arabah, the mountain slopes, the wilderness and the Negev. These were the lands of the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites. These were the kings:
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Jericho one the king of Ai (near Bethel) one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Jerusalem one the king of Hebron one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Jarmuth one the king of Lachish one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Eglon one the king of Gezer one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Debir one the king of Geder one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Hormah one the king of Arad one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Libnah one the king of Adullam one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Makkedah one the king of Bethel one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Tappuah one the king of Hepher one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Aphek one the king of Lasharon one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Madon one the king of Hazor one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Shimron Meron one the king of Akshaph one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Taanach one the king of Megiddo one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Kedesh one the king of Jokneam in Carmel one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Dor (in Naphoth Dor) one the king of Goyim in Gilgal one
speaker: Narrator

text: the king of Tirzah onethirty-one kings in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua had grown old, the Lord said to him, ‘You are now very old, and there are still very large areas of land to be taken over.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is the land that remains: all the regions of the Philistines and Geshurites,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the River Shihor on the east of Egypt to the territory of Ekron on the north, all of it counted as Canaanite though held by the five Philistine rulers in Gaza, Ashdod, Ashkelon, Gath and Ekron; the territory of the Avvites
speaker: Narrator

text: on the south; all the land of the Canaanites, from Arah of the Sidonians as far as Aphek and the border of the Amorites;
speaker: Narrator

text: the area of Byblos; and all Lebanon to the east, from Baal Gad below Mount Hermon to Lebo Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As for all the inhabitants of the mountain regions from Lebanon to Misrephoth Maim, that is, all the Sidonians, I myself will drive them out before the Israelites. Be sure to allocate this land to Israel for an inheritance, as I have instructed you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and divide it as an inheritance among the nine tribes and half of the tribe of Manasseh.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The other half of Manasseh, the Reubenites and the Gadites had received the inheritance that Moses had given them east of the Jordan, as he, the servant of the Lord, had assigned it to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: It extended from Aroer on the rim of the Arnon Gorge, and from the town in the middle of the gorge, and included the whole plateau of Medeba as far as Dibon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the towns of Sihon king of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon, out to the border of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: It also included Gilead, the territory of the people of Geshur and Maakah, all of Mount Hermon and all Bashan as far as Salekah –
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, the whole kingdom of Og in Bashan, who had reigned in Ashtaroth and Edrei. (He was the last of the Rephaites.) Moses had defeated them and taken over their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites did not drive out the people of Geshur and Maakah, so they continue to live among the Israelites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the tribe of Levi he gave no inheritance, since the food offerings presented to the Lord, the God of Israel, are their inheritance, as he promised them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what Moses had given to the tribe of Reuben, according to its clans:
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory from Aroer on the rim of the Arnon Gorge, and from the town in the middle of the gorge, and the whole plateau past Medeba
speaker: Narrator

text: to Heshbon and all its towns on the plateau, including Dibon, Bamoth Baal, Beth Baal Meon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahaz, Kedemoth, Mephaath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kiriathaim, Sibmah, Zereth Shahar on the hill in the valley,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Peor, the slopes of Pisgah, and Beth Jeshimoth
speaker: Narrator

text: – all the towns on the plateau and the entire realm of Sihon king of the Amorites, who ruled at Heshbon. Moses had defeated him and the Midianite chiefs, Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur and Reba – princes allied with Sihon – who lived in that country.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition to those slain in battle, the Israelites had put to the sword Balaam son of Beor, who practised divination.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary of the Reubenites was the bank of the Jordan. These towns and their villages were the inheritance of the Reubenites, according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what Moses had given to the tribe of Gad, according to its clans:
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory of Jazer, all the towns of Gilead and half the Ammonite country as far as Aroer, near Rabbah;
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Heshbon to Ramath Mizpah and Betonim, and from Mahanaim to the territory of Debir;
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the valley, Beth Haram, Beth Nimrah, Sukkoth and Zaphon with the rest of the realm of Sihon king of Heshbon (the east side of the Jordan, the territory up to the end of the Sea of Galilee).
speaker: Narrator

text: These towns and their villages were the inheritance of the Gadites, according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what Moses had given to the half-tribe of Manasseh, that is, to half the family of the descendants of Manasseh, according to its clans:
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory extending from Mahanaim and including all of Bashan, the entire realm of Og king of Bashan – all the settlements of Jair in Bashan, sixty towns,
speaker: Narrator

text: half of Gilead, and Ashtaroth and Edrei (the royal cities of Og in Bashan). This was for the descendants of Makir son of Manasseh – for half of the sons of Makir, according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the inheritance Moses had given when he was in the plains of Moab across the Jordan east of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the tribe of Levi, Moses had given no inheritance; the Lord, the God of Israel, is their inheritance, as he promised them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the areas the Israelites received as an inheritance in the land of Canaan, which Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun and the heads of the tribal clans of Israel allotted to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their inheritances were assigned by lot to the nine-and-a-half tribes, as the Lord had commanded through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses had granted the two-and-a-half tribes their inheritance east of the Jordan but had not granted the Levites an inheritance among the rest,
speaker: Narrator

text: for Joseph’s descendants had become two tribes – Manasseh and Ephraim. The Levites received no share of the land but only towns to live in, with pasture-lands for their flocks and herds.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites divided the land, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the people of Judah approached Joshua at Gilgal, and Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite said to him, ‘You know what the Lord said to Moses the man of God at Kadesh Barnea about you and me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was forty years old when Moses the servant of the Lord sent me from Kadesh Barnea to explore the land. And I brought him back a report according to my convictions,
speaker: Narrator

text: but my fellow Israelites who went up with me made the hearts of the people sink. I, however, followed the Lord my God wholeheartedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: So on that day Moses swore to me, “The land on which your feet have walked will be your inheritance and that of your children for ever, because you have followed the Lord my God wholeheartedly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now then, just as the Lord promised, he has kept me alive for forty-five years since the time he said this to Moses, while Israel moved about in the wilderness. So here I am today, eighty-five years old!
speaker: Narrator

text: I am still as strong today as the day Moses sent me out; I’m just as vigorous to go out to battle now as I was then.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now give me this hill country that the Lord promised me that day. You yourself heard then that the Anakites were there and their cities were large and fortified, but, the Lord helping me, I will drive them out just as he said.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua blessed Caleb son of Jephunneh and gave him Hebron as his inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hebron has belonged to Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite ever since, because he followed the Lord, the God of Israel, wholeheartedly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
(Hebron used to be called Kiriath Arba after Arba, who was the greatest man among the Anakites.)
Then the land had rest from war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land allotted to the tribe of Judah, according to its clans, extended down to the territory of Edom, to the Desert of Zin in the extreme south.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their southern boundary started from the bay at the southern end of the Dead Sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: crossed south of Scorpion Pass, continued on to Zin and went over to the south of Kadesh Barnea. Then it ran past Hezron up to Addar and curved around to Karka.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then passed along to Azmon and joined the Wadi of Egypt, ending at the Mediterranean Sea. This is their southern boundary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eastern boundary is the Dead Sea as far as the mouth of the Jordan.
The northern boundary started from the bay of the sea at the mouth of the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: went up to Beth Hoglah and continued north of Beth Arabah to the Stone of Bohan son of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary then went up to Debir from the Valley of Achor and turned north to Gilgal, which faces the Pass of Adummim south of the gorge. It continued along to the waters of En Shemesh and came out at En Rogel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it ran up the Valley of Ben Hinnom along the southern slope of the Jebusite city (that is, Jerusalem). From there it climbed to the top of the hill west of the Hinnom Valley at the northern end of the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the hilltop the boundary headed towards the spring of the waters of Nephtoah, came out at the towns of Mount Ephron and went down towards Baalah (that is, Kiriath Jearim).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it curved westward from Baalah to Mount Seir, ran along the northern slope of Mount Jearim (that is, Kesalon), continued down to Beth Shemesh and crossed to Timnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It went to the northern slope of Ekron, turned toward Shikkeron, passed along to Mount Baalah and reached Jabneel. The boundary ended at the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The western boundary is the coastline of the Mediterranean Sea.
These are the boundaries around the people of Judah by their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: In accordance with the Lord’s command to him, Joshua gave to Caleb son of Jephunneh a portion in Judah – Kiriath Arba, that is, Hebron. (Arba was the forefather of Anak.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From Hebron Caleb drove out the three Anakites – Sheshai, Ahiman and Talmai, the sons of Anak.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he marched against the people living in Debir (formerly called Kiriath Sepher).
speaker: Narrator

text: And Caleb said, ‘I will give my daughter Aksah in marriage to the man who attacks and captures Kiriath Sepher.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s brother, took it; so Caleb gave his daughter Aksah to him in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when she came to Othniel, she urged him to ask her father for a field. When she got off her donkey, Caleb asked her, ‘What can I do for you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: She replied, ‘Do me a special favour. Since you have given me land in the Negev, give me also springs of water.’ So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the inheritance of the tribe of Judah, according to its clans:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The southernmost towns of the tribe of Judah in the Negev towards the boundary of Edom were:
Kabzeel, Eder, Jagur,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kinah, Dimonah, Adadah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedesh, Hazor, Ithnan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziph, Telem, Bealoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazor Hadattah, Kerioth Hezron (that is, Hazor),
speaker: Narrator

text: Amam, Shema, Moladah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazar Gaddah, Heshmon, Beth Pelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazar Shual, Beersheba, Biziothiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Baalah, Iyim, Ezem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eltolad, Kesil, Hormah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziklag, Madmannah, Sansannah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lebaoth, Shilhim, Ain and Rimmon – a total of twenty-nine towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the western foothills:
Eshtaol, Zorah, Ashnah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zanoah, En Gannim, Tappuah, Enam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jarmuth, Adullam, Sokoh, Azekah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaaraim, Adithaim and Gederah (or Gederothaim) – fourteen towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zenan, Hadashah, Migdal Gad,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dilean, Mizpah, Joktheel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lachish, Bozkath, Eglon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kabbon, Lahmas, Kitlish,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gederoth, Beth Dagon, Naamah and Makkedah – sixteen towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Libnah, Ether, Ashan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Iphtah, Ashnah, Nezib,
speaker: Narrator

text: Keilah, Akzib and Mareshah – nine towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ekron, with its surrounding settlements and villages;
speaker: Narrator

text: west of Ekron, all that were in the vicinity of Ashdod, together with their villages;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ashdod, its surrounding settlements and villages; and Gaza, its settlements and villages, as far as the Wadi of Egypt and the coastline of the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the hill country:
Shamir, Jattir, Sokoh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dannah, Kiriath Sannah (that is, Debir),
speaker: Narrator

text: Anab, Eshtemoh, Anim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Goshen, Holon and Giloh – eleven towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arab, Dumah, Eshan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Janim, Beth Tappuah, Aphekah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Humtah, Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) and Zior – nine towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maon, Carmel, Ziph, Juttah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezreel, Jokdeam, Zanoah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kain, Gibeah and Timnah – ten towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Halhul, Beth Zur, Gedor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Maarath, Beth Anoth and Eltekon – six towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kiriath Baal (that is, Kiriath Jearim) and Rabbah – two towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the wilderness:
Beth Arabah, Middin, Sekakah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nibshan, the City of Salt and En Gedi – six towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah could not dislodge the Jebusites, who were living in Jerusalem; to this day the Jebusites live there with the people of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land allotted to Joseph began at the Jordan, east of the springs of Jericho, and went up from there through the desert into the hill country of Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It went on from Bethel (that is, Luz), crossed over to the territory of the Arkites in Ataroth,
speaker: Narrator

text: descended westward to the territory of the Japhletites as far as the region of Lower Beth Horon and on to Gezer, ending at the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Manasseh and Ephraim, the descendants of Joseph, received their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This was the territory of Ephraim, according to its clans:
The boundary of their inheritance went from Ataroth Addar in the east to Upper Beth Horon
speaker: Narrator

text: and continued to the Mediterranean Sea. From Mikmethath on the north it curved eastward to Taanath Shiloh, passing by it to Janoah on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it went down from Janoah to Ataroth and Naarah, touched Jericho and came out at the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Tappuah the border went west to the Kanah Ravine and ended at the Mediterranean Sea. This was the inheritance of the tribe of the Ephraimites, according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: It also included all the towns and their villages that were set aside for the Ephraimites within the inheritance of the Manassites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not dislodge the Canaanites living in Gezer; to this day the Canaanites live among the people of Ephraim but are required to do forced labour.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the land allotted to the tribe of Manasseh as Joseph’s firstborn, that is, for Makir, Manasseh’s firstborn. Makir was the ancestor of the Gileadites, who had received Gilead and Bashan because the Makirites were great soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this land was allotted to the rest of the people of Manasseh – the clans of Abiezer, Helek, Asriel, Shechem, Hepher and Shemida. These are the other male descendants of Manasseh son of Joseph by their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zelophehad son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Makir, the son of Manasseh, had no sons but only daughters, whose names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milkah and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the leaders and said, ‘The Lord commanded Moses to give us an inheritance among our relatives.’ So Joshua gave them an inheritance along with the brothers of their father, according to the Lord’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh’s share consisted of ten tracts of land besides Gilead and Bashan east of the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the daughters of the tribe of Manasseh received an inheritance among the sons. The land of Gilead belonged to the rest of the descendants of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory of Manasseh extended from Asher to Mikmethath east of Shechem. The boundary ran southward from there to include the people living at En Tappuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Manasseh had the land of Tappuah, but Tappuah itself, on the boundary of Manasseh, belonged to the Ephraimites.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the boundary continued south to the Kanah Ravine. There were towns belonging to Ephraim lying among the towns of Manasseh, but the boundary of Manasseh was the northern side of the ravine and ended at the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the south the land belonged to Ephraim, on the north to Manasseh. The territory of Manasseh reached the Mediterranean Sea and bordered Asher on the north and Issachar on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within Issachar and Asher, Manasseh also had Beth Shan, Ibleam and the people of Dor, Endor, Taanach and Megiddo, together with their surrounding settlements (the third in the list is Naphoth).
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Manassites were not able to occupy these towns, for the Canaanites were determined to live in that region.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, when the Israelites grew stronger, they subjected the Canaanites to forced labour but did not drive them out completely.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Joseph said to Joshua, ‘Why have you allotted us only one portion of land and one share for an inheritance? We are a numerous people, and the Lord has blessed us abundantly.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If you are so numerous,’ Joshua answered, ‘and if the hill country of Ephraim is too small for you, go up into the forest and clear land for yourselves there in the land of the Perizzites and Rephaites.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Joseph replied, ‘The hill country is not enough for us, and all the Canaanites who live in the plain have chariots fitted with iron, both those in Beth Shan and its settlements and those in the Valley of Jezreel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joshua said to the tribes of Joseph – to Ephraim and Manasseh – ‘You are numerous and very powerful. You will have not only one portion of land allotted to you
speaker: Narrator

text: but the forested hill country as well. Clear it, and its farthest limits will be yours; though the Canaanites have chariots fitted with iron and though they are strong, you can drive them out.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole assembly of the Israelites gathered at Shiloh and set up the tent of meeting there. The country was brought under their control,
speaker: Narrator

text: but there were still seven Israelite tribes who had not yet received their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua said to the Israelites: ‘How long will you wait before you begin to take possession of the land that the Lord, the God of your ancestors, has given you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Appoint three men from each tribe. I will send them out to make a survey of the land and to write a description of it, according to the inheritance of each. Then they will return to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to divide the land into seven parts. Judah is to remain in its territory on the south and the tribes of Joseph in their territory on the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you have written descriptions of the seven parts of the land, bring them here to me and I will cast lots for you in the presence of the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites, however, do not get a portion among you, because the priestly service of the Lord is their inheritance. And Gad, Reuben and the half-tribe of Manasseh have already received their inheritance on the east side of the Jordan. Moses the servant of the Lord gave it to them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As the men started on their way to map out the land, Joshua instructed them, ‘Go and make a survey of the land and write a description of it. Then return to me, and I will cast lots for you here at Shiloh in the presence of the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men left and went through the land. They wrote its description on a scroll, town by town, in seven parts, and returned to Joshua in the camp at Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua then cast lots for them in Shiloh in the presence of the Lord, and there he distributed the land to the Israelites according to their tribal divisions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first lot came up for the tribe of Benjamin according to its clans. Their allotted territory lay between the tribes of Judah and Joseph:
speaker: Narrator

text: On the north side their boundary began at the Jordan, passed the northern slope of Jericho and headed west into the hill country, coming out at the wilderness of Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there it crossed to the south slope of Luz (that is, Bethel) and went down to Ataroth Addar on the hill south of Lower Beth Horon.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the hill facing Beth Horon on the south the boundary turned south along the western side and came out at Kiriath Baal (that is, Kiriath Jearim), a town of the people of Judah. This was the western side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The southern side began at the outskirts of Kiriath Jearim on the west, and the boundary came out at the spring of the waters of Nephtoah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary went down to the foot of the hill facing the Valley of Ben Hinnom, north of the Valley of Rephaim. It continued down the Hinnom Valley along the southern slope of the Jebusite city and so to En Rogel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then curved north, went to En Shemesh, continued to Geliloth, which faces the Pass of Adummim, and ran down to the Stone of Bohan son of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: It continued to the northern slope of Beth Arabah and on down into the Arabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then went to the northern slope of Beth Hoglah and came out at the northern bay of the Dead Sea, at the mouth of the Jordan in the south. This was the southern boundary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Jordan formed the boundary on the eastern side.
These were the boundaries that marked out the inheritance of the clans of Benjamin on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tribe of Benjamin, according to its clans, had the following cities:
Jericho, Beth Hoglah, Emek Keziz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Arabah, Zemaraim, Bethel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Avvim, Parah, Ophrah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kephar Ammoni, Ophni and Geba – twelve towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gibeon, Ramah, Beeroth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mizpah, Kephirah, Mozah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rekem, Irpeel, Taralah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zelah, Haeleph, the Jebusite city (that is, Jerusalem), Gibeah and Kiriath – fourteen towns and their villages.
This was the inheritance of Benjamin for its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second lot came out for the tribe of Simeon according to its clans. Their inheritance lay within the territory of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It included:
Beersheba (or Sheba), Moladah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazar Shual, Balah, Ezem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eltolad, Bethul, Hormah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziklag, Beth Markaboth, Hazar Susah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Lebaoth and Sharuhen – thirteen towns and their villages;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ain, Rimmon, Ether and Ashan – four towns and their villages –
speaker: Narrator

text:
and all the villages around these towns as far as Baalath Beer (Ramah in the Negev).
This was the inheritance of the tribe of the Simeonites, according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inheritance of the Simeonites was taken from the share of Judah, because Judah’s portion was more than they needed. So the Simeonites received their inheritance within the territory of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The third lot came up for Zebulun according to its clans:
The boundary of their inheritance went as far as Sarid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Going west it ran to Maralah, touched Dabbesheth, and extended to the ravine near Jokneam.
speaker: Narrator

text: It turned east from Sarid towards the sunrise to the territory of Kisloth Tabor and went on to Daberath and up to Japhia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it continued eastward to Gath Hepher and Eth Kazin; it came out at Rimmon and turned towards Neah.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the boundary went round on the north to Hannathon and ended at the Valley of Iphtah El.
speaker: Narrator

text: Included were Kattath, Nahalal, Shimron, Idalah and Bethlehem. There were twelve towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: These towns and their villages were the inheritance of Zebulun, according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth lot came out for Issachar according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their territory included:
Jezreel, Kesulloth, Shunem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hapharaim, Shion, Anaharath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rabbith, Kishion, Ebez,
speaker: Narrator

text: Remeth, En Gannim, En Haddah and Beth Pazzez.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary touched Tabor, Shahazumah and Beth Shemesh, and ended at the Jordan. There were sixteen towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: These towns and their villages were the inheritance of the tribe of Issachar, according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth lot came out for the tribe of Asher according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their territory included:
Helkath, Hali, Beten, Akshaph,
speaker: Narrator

text: Allammelek, Amad and Mishal. On the west the boundary touched Carmel and Shihor Libnath.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then turned east towards Beth Dagon, touched Zebulun and the Valley of Iphtah El, and went north to Beth Emek and Neiel, passing Kabul on the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: It went to Abdon, Rehob, Hammon and Kanah, as far as Greater Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary then turned back towards Ramah and went to the fortified city of Tyre, turned towards Hosah and came out at the Mediterranean Sea in the region of Akzib,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ummah, Aphek and Rehob. There were twenty-two towns and their villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: These towns and their villages were the inheritance of the tribe of Asher, according to its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth lot came out for Naphtali according to its clans:
speaker: Narrator

text: Their boundary went from Heleph and the large tree in Zaanannim, passing Adami Nekeb and Jabneel to Lakkum and ending at the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary ran west through Aznoth Tabor and came out at Hukkok. It touched Zebulun on the south, Asher on the west and the Jordan on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fortified cities were Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Kinnereth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adamah, Ramah, Hazor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedesh, Edrei, En Hazor,
speaker: Narrator
